title: Half-life - decay times for unequal-mass samples

content.question: A sample of a radioactive element has an initial mass <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, and it takes a time <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> for one half of the atoms in the sample to decay. Another sample of the radioactive element with the same initial mass <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> is divided into two smaller samples of unequal mass. It is observed that the time for half of atoms in the less massive sample to decay is <math alttext="t sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></mstyle></math> and the time for half of the atoms in the more massive sample to decay is <math alttext="t sub M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>M</mi></msub></mstyle></math>. Which of the following correctly relates <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="t sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="t sub M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>M</mi></msub></mstyle></math>?
